description: A transitional time calls for its own (weird, tangy) transitional drinks.
title: Come September
title_page: Come September - The New York Times
text:
Photo
Oh, the days grow short when we reach September. Kurt Weill and Maxwell Anderson got that right in “September Song,” didn’t they? Cheerful it’s not, but for a year in my early 20s, the only music I could stand to hear was Weill’s. I was adrift, and politically charged cabaret numbers — often sung in a language I did not understand — somehow anchored me. I downed plenty of whiskey back then (and still do), but as with music, my taste in drinks was growing up. It was then that I first made a martini, first tasted absinthe and could, for the first time, call myself a regular at a New York bar — one where an indulgent bartender might sometimes pop onto the sound system the Lotte Lenya tape I just happened to have in my backpack.
Even now, I return to Weill at the beginning of every autumn. The music sets the tone for the season to come, evoking a peculiar feeling of nostalgia not only for the past but also for the right-now: for pulling sweaters and blankets out from under the bed, for fallen foliage and the back-to-business resolve of fall. Though I will welcome a full-fledged reunion with brown liquor and its comforts soon enough, this in-between time calls for in-between drinks. Summer seems to insist that we return its favors with equal sunniness in a glass. Late September doesn’t mind if we let a few shadows in. And where cocktails are concerned, this can get interesting, without any undue gravitas.
Photo
What I want now are cocktails reflective of the changing of seasons: a little moody and weird, both as bitter and as sweet as autumn itself, and as evocative and transporting as a Weill song. They’re suggestive of the Weimar Republic era from which his music emerged — drinks I could imagine Sally Bowles knocking back (one is called, fittingly, the Cabaret Cocktail). Christopher Isherwood, Bowles’s creator and a fine chronicler of the time, wrote with longing of drinking claret and cheap Cognac in “Goodbye to Berlin.” I imagine there must be a long compound word in German for the pleasure that can attach itself to a certain variety of tolerable, low-grade melancholia, and that’s fine by me. Whether it’s brought on by too much cheap Cognac is up to you.
So as the wind picks up and the skies darken earlier, I always go for liquors I don’t turn to very often: the bite of kirsch and the dream-inducing anise zest of absinthe, the herbaceous, medicinal tang of Benedictine and the neon-hued mysteries of its monastic kin, Chartreuse. And also schnapps.
The vintage cocktails offered here might not be drinks I would mix up for everyday satisfaction. In September, though, I want to play with unusual flavors and colors. “September Song” reminds us to make the most of these precious days. That should include drinking well, too.
ON SCHNAPPS
Katherine Pence, a historian at Baruch College, pointed me toward an essay, ‘‘On the Mixing of Delicious Schnapps,’’ by Weill’s contemporary Erich Maria Remarque, a cocktail enthusiast and the author of ‘‘All Quiet on the Western Front.’’ ‘‘It is easier to write about the psychology of a woman than to understand a schnapps,’’ Remarque wrote. ‘‘Schnapps has a soul.’’ I’ve experimented with mixing a cocktail to Remarque’s specs. Good schnapps isn’t always easy to find in the United States, but I think old-school cocktails like the Albertine and the Cabaret come close to what he had in mind.
